Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: The snow was coming down in thick, blinding sheets as I navigated the cab through icy streets. My passenger, a nervous businessman, kept glancing at his watch, reminding me that his international flight was leaving in less than an hour. Every red light, every cautious turn, I felt his impatience pressing on me. As a taxi driver, I was expected to get him there safely and on time, but the roads were treacherous, and I couldn’t risk an accident. My phone buzzed with a reminder: in thirty minutes, I was supposed to meet Mrs. Alvarez at the church. She’d confided in me last Sunday, her voice trembling, about a struggle she couldn’t face alone. As her priest, I was her lifeline, expected to listen, to guide, to be present. The weight of both roles pressed on me—one demanded speed and focus, the other compassion and presence. My hands tightened on the wheel, heart pounding, as I wrestled with the impossible choice between duty and devotion, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
